content: The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" requires reports on claims for disabilities caused by military sexual trauma. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" mandates annual reports on claims for disabilities caused by military sexual trauma, including the number and details of covered claims submitted each fiscal year. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" requires annual reports on approved and denied claims for disabilities caused by military sexual trauma, including details on the number and percentage of claims by sex, reasons for denials, and the number of denials due to failure to report for a medical examination. The annual report required by the "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" includes details on pending claims, appeals, average processing time, and training provided to employees of the Veterans Benefits Administration for disability compensation claims related to covered mental health conditions. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" defines "covered mental health conditions" as PTSD, anxiety, depression, or other mental health diagnoses related to military sexual trauma. Military sexual trauma is defined as psychological trauma resulting from sexual assault, battery, or harassment during active military service. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" defines "covered mental health conditions" related to military sexual trauma as PTSD, anxiety, depression, or other mental health diagnoses. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to submit an initial report to Congress on claims for disabilities related to military sexual trauma within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Congress urges the Secretary to update regulations regarding military sexual trauma to improve the service-connection of post-traumatic stress disorder. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is urged to update regulations to improve service-connection for post-traumatic stress disorder related to military sexual trauma, recognizing a range of resulting disabilities. During a specified period, veterans with covered claims or treatment for military sexual trauma will receive information. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is urged to update regulations for service-connection related to post-traumatic stress disorder from military sexual trauma. Veterans with covered claims or treatment will receive monthly updates on grant/denial rates and planned improvements. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide monthly updates on grant/denial rates and processing times for covered claims related to post-traumatic stress disorder. This information will be available on the Department's website and submitted to Congress regularly. The monthly report will include a list of adjudicated covered claims, outcomes for each medical condition, and reasons for claim denials. Military Sexual Trauma is defined in this section as per Title 38, United States Code.
